sentence.text: Patient S, a 7 -month-old male infant, was referred for evaluation of excessive crying and bilateral painful, non-progressive shin swellings noted since the 3rd month of life.
There was no history of associated fever or rashes, swollen joints or swellings elsewhere in the body.
No cardiovascular, respiratory or gastrointestinal symptoms were present.
The antenatal, perinatal and neonatal periods had been uneventful and all developmental milestones had been attained normally.
There was no history suggestive of preceding trauma, drug intake or physical abuse.
This child was the first offspring of non-consanguineous parents.
There was no history of either parent or any other family member having had similar problems during his/her childhood.
The growth parameters were appropriate for age, with the anthropometric measurements corresponding to 25th–50th centile values for 7 months and the nutritional status was good.
Examination revealed tender, diffuse, immobile swellings over the anterior aspect of both the legs, which were hard in consistency (Fig. 1).
The neighboring knee and ankle joints appeared to be normal.
There were no swellings over the jaw, clavicles or ribs or elsewhere on the body.
There was no evidence of joint laxity or skin hyper extensibility.
The rest of the general and systemic examination findings were normal.
There were no clinical signs suggestive of physical abuse.
On developmental assessment, the psychomotor development was found to be appropriate for age.

Skeletal survey radiographs showed evidence of significant periosteal elevation, new bone formation and cortical thickening involving the diaphyses of the tibial bones bilaterally, along with a milder degree of cortical hyperostosis involving both the femoral bones (Fig. 1).
The knee and ankle joints were normal.
The other long bones of the limbs, the ribs and the mandible did not show any significant periosteal changes.
The serum alkaline phosphatase level was elevated (630 U/L; normal range 145–420 U/L); but the serum calcium (9.5 mg/dL) and phosphorus (5.5 mg/dL) levels were within the normal range.
VDRL serology was negative.
The hemogram, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, random blood sugar, serum creatinine, liver function tests and urine examination findings were all within the normal reference range.
As the clinical and radiological findings suggested the diagnosis of infantile cortical hyperostosis, genetic screening of COL1A1 was performed.
The sequencing of exon 41 of COL1A1, as described by Gensure et al., confirmed the heterozygous mutation c.3040 C>T (p.R1014C) in the proband
